[snip multi-assert arguments already answered by David]

> Also, it seems to me your recommended pattern for code that must
throw an
> exception ("don't catch it and declare the exception in the throws
> statement") goes against common practice. Plus, it will cause JUnit to
> report an Error instead of a Failure, although this distinction is
> thankfully going away with JUnit4.
>
> A more common way to address this problem is to catch the exception
and do a
> fail().

Hi Cédric,

I would argue that explicitly calling fail is less useful than
propagating the exception outside of the test method, mainly because
the stack trace is lost. I've been caught a number of times myself
when a test failed because of an unexpected exception, but it was
non-trivial to track down the line that caused the exception. The
stack trace will show this information directly, any good JUnit test
runners will display the stack trace. IDEs will even take you to the
line of code, as well.

Therefore I think the advice in the anti-patterns article regarding
exceptions is sound.

> Other than that, your guide is fine advice.

Thanks!
